This is a pretty compressed but well thought out book. It attempts to point out and understand the mechanics in which people and all living creatures are "hard-wired" to through genetics. This gene-centric view of behavior was suggested ever since their discovery but was introduced to pop-science by Richard Dawkins in the "The Selfish Gene (1974)." Dawkin's argument, along with many, was that creatures DO NOT work for the good of the whole but are rather "vessels" in which our genes are the captains driving evolution through ever changing environmental issues and competition. For example: a male crocodile, even on the steady course toward extinction, will kill babies of another male so that his own genes are selected for the next generation of crocs. The more suitable thing to do in order to sustain their species would be to allow all babies to live and mate as well. If they were thinking for the good of the whole, this would be the case.Cooperation in certain species is looked at as an evolutionary adaptation in order to establish a system in which common goals within a species are met. Monogomy would be a prime example of this adaptation.Through all the in depth examinations on how genes operate and why, the main point that Matt Ridley is making is that evolution is a treadmill and not a ladder. He references The Red Queen from "Through the Looking Glass," a sequel to Alice in Wonderland in which Alice encounters a character who must run in order to stay in one place. If she does not run, she falls behind. And of course, to move forward she must run even faster. Evolution to Matt Ridley and most evolutionary biologist is a chess-like stalemate.After finally reaching the last few chapters of the book, I realized that reading the first half was a waste of time because, while his thesis is claimed throughout these chapters, too many references are used for every single little idea that he presents. It was almost as if he was afraid of not using enough citations but got progressively relaxed as the book moved forward.As soon as I'm done reading this gem, I will leave a more detailed review about the specific ideas that are laid out. Stay-tuned and buy this book if you are interested in the nature of human relationships and are even wanting to improve the way that you interact with the opposite sex. It is even recommended by Neil Strauss ("The Game"). Don't buy it strictly for this cause as it mainly deals with the evolutionary aspect of human relationships.

The primary reason I picked up this book is because it seemed as though it would aid me in understanding r/k reproductive strategies. Though not the primary feature or goal of this book, it did so indirectly when discussing some related topics. Basically, this book describes the basics of evolution and how it dances on the floor provided by the genetics of various species in general and human species in particular. Everything in this book, as the title suggests is described in context of the theory of "The Red Queen." The term is derived from "Through the Looking Glass," by Lewis Carroll, where the chess piece runs but doesn't get anywhere:  "The most curious part of the thing was, that the trees and the other things  round them never changed their places at all: however fast they went, they never  seemed to pass anything. "I wonder if all the things move along with us?" thought  poor puzzled Alice. And the Queen seemed to guess her thoughts, for she cried,  "Faster! Don't try to talk!""  ---Lewis Carroll, Through the Looking-GlassIn terms of evolution, essentially it is the evolutionary drive in species to not merely seek reproductive advantage, but also simply to survive. Both sexual and asexual theories are investigated as well as the roles of culture and gender. A great feature of this book, which I really liked, was the manner in which Ridley explains the differences in the male and female mind in an non-dogmatic way... unfettered by what is religiously or socially acceptable.Most people shouldn't have an opinion on evolution to begin with. This is a personal opinion but the reader will perhaps agree that, when some of the people who are coming from a religious perspective often seem to be too blinded to want to understand the basic premises and theories that the evolutionary scientists are trying to put forth and in doing so they betray their dogmatism; and on the other side even when there is a person who considers themselves a proponent of evolutionary theory, more often then not does not understand it well enough to explain anything in any meaningful way, and by not budging from 'established science' they betray their dogmatism as well. For both of these personalities the preacher or the scientist essentially serve the same function. But for the reader with an open mind and a longing to understand, this book will be well worth the time.End.

A thorough and thought-provoking examination of evolution. The "Red Queen" in the title refers to the character in "Through the Looking Glass" who has to run as fast as possible just to stay in one place. As Ridley explains, evolution is not a progression to every greater complexity and refinement, but instead is a race where every organism has to continually adapt to competition between species and within its own race just to keep its place. The concept of evolution as a progressive improvement, where simple bacteria lead to multicellular animals, eventually producing its "greatest" achievement: man, is simply wrong. Each species evolves to best survive in its environment, not to become "better" or "more evolved." Species like the coelacanth and many reptiles (alligators and turtles, for instance) are little changed over many millions of years - the fact that they haven't "improved" isn't a failure on their part, but actually a sign of how well they've succeeded in competing with other species.Ridley builds on this background to lay out his most interesting (and probably more controversial) thesis in the latter part of the book. How man developed such a large brain is a bit of a puzzle. It grants us self-awareness and mental abilities beyond any other animal but comes at a great cost. We're born far more immature and helpless than other primates, primarily because our heads are so large that they make childbirth difficult. We then require far longer to develop and mature, to allow time for our bodies and brains to grow to adult size. Once mature the brain consume an inordinate amount of the body's total energy, forcing us to maintain a high-calorie diet. Although it does allow us to communicate, reason, and build tools, many other animals manage these feats (admittedly to a lesser degree) with far smaller, less expensive brains. Why did ours grow exponentially while other primates were able to get by with much smaller ones? Ridley proposes that our big brains developed, at least in part, due to sexual selection effects - they're our equivalent of showy peacock feathers! He admits that much of his theory is speculative (although he includes quite a few supporting facts and corresponding references), and I'm not sure I buy the entire argument, but it seems like a reasonable explanation.

The Red Queen begins with a question: why do creatures have sex? Why did it evolve? The answer, Matt Ridley believes, lies in the principle of the Red Queen. A character featured in Lewis Carroll's Through the Looking Glass, she announced to Alice that in her world, it took all the running one could do simply to remain in one place. This characterizes the constant struggle for domination between species in the natural world, a struggle between creatures not only visible to us, but between parasites within our bodies and our immune systems. Every move is countered, every success overturned; such is the impetus for evolution. In The Red Queen, Ridley explains his reasoning, and demonstrates how evolutionary principles subtly drive the expression of human sexuality. There's a lot of tension in this work, first when Ridley makes his case and somehow incorporates aspects of evolution from disparate camps (gene-centered, individually-driven, species-based) , and in the heart of the book as he examines the implications. This is especially true in the chapters, "Polygamy and the Nature of Men" and "Monogamy and the Nature of Women": while it is true men have a genetic inclination to sow seeds and women one to invest in a partner, behavior as studied indicates that things are not to trite. In the last chapters of the book, Ridley looks at sexuality as a possible cause of advanced human intelligence (competition and tension between the sexes and individuals), which is amusing given the power sexual interest has to render victims dumbstruck and seemingly foolish.  Since its publication, The Red Queen has proven influential; I knew of it long before I read it because of its place in the literature, being cited often. That may attest to the science, which is is speculative but sensible based on what he presents. He certainly makes for an entertaining author, one whose arguments are open to virtually anyone regardless of scientific reading; he begins with a technical, biological edge before spending most of the book on behavior -- a softer, fuzzier realm for readers.

"...in a species such as a peafowl, where female choice of mate rules, the male is not entirely a passive spectator of his evolutionary fate. He is both an ardent suitor and an eager salesman: He has a product to sellâhis genes, perhapsâand information to impart about that product, but he does not simply hand the information over and await the peahen's decision. He is out to persuade her, to seduce her. And just as she is descended from females who made a careful choice, so he is descended from males who made a hard sell." - The Red QueenWhile much of the book describes the reasons organisms engage in sexual reproduction and details many species' mating habits, it is always illustrative of a greater point about human nature. The arguments and insights presented about human nature are endlessly interesting while maintaining intellectual honesty and objectivity. They are well worth it after working through the preliminary chapters. You'll find yourself at several points in the book setting it down to contemplate the richness of the ideas being presented; the Red Queen was one of the most fascinating, illuminating books I've ever read.Some interesting concepts:1. (crudely summarizing) your genes control you in order to pass themselves on--your body is the vehicle to do so and sexual human nature the means to do so.2. Humans are monogamous animals with highly adulterous natures; even rulers with over 1,000 women in their harems were devoted to a wife.3. After kindness and intelligence: Men are more concerned with a potential mate's youth and beauty; women are more concerned with a potential mate's wealth and status. Want to know the reasons? Read the book!4. In the name of sexual selection, males in a species will add on ridiculous ornaments for the ladies even if those ornaments make it more challenging for the males to catch food, fly, etc.5. Fashion is arbitrary. Females select males with X feature because other females select males with X feature.If you enjoyed this book, I highly recommend you read Sex At Dawn by Christopher Ryan and The Selfish Gene by Richard Dawkins.

First two thirds of the book were good, although its date is starting to show in places. (Twenty years is a long time in science.) Then I got to the chapter 'Sexing The Mind' and almost threw the book across the room. Plenty of fallacies, mostly having to do with the invisibility of the female experience to male scientists who are, consciously or not, invested in preserving the status quo- in which male access to enormous amounts of unpaid female labor in childrearing, cooking, and cleaning is enormously beneficial to males. (At one point I felt like screaming at the author that spatial navigation skills would be just as important to gatherers as to hunters. You still have to know where things are to bring them home. This is just common sense!) The author also plays down the influence of culture- nature is clearly the driver, not nurture, in Ridley's worldview, and he pooh-poohs the ongoing debate as overblown. Girls don't try to break into male dominated professions (to borrow one of the author's examples, auto mechanics) because they just don't like those things, not because men would ever be dicks when defending the boys' club. In short, when the author is on firm biology ground, the book is fairly good. When he strays into sociobiology, pyschology, or worst of all evo psych, things become far more dubious.

A well-researched, educational, intellectually convincing book on the intertwined, circular relationship of evolution with sex based on the Red Queen evolutionary hypothesis that states living organisms must continually & constantly evolve to gain reproductive advantage & survive alongside other species that are likewise progressively evolving in a volatile changing environment. Human evolution is made possible by sexual reproduction, & Ridley contends it is hard to understand human beings' sexual nature & motivations without understanding how sexuality evolved. Courtship/dating rituals, marriage, sexual habits, and family creation are partly the result of the choices & decisions we make in who to make love with or to marry. These "choices", in turn, are partly determined by genetic imprints that have been present in the brain for millennia (nature), & partly by learned cultural behavior (nurture). I appreciated this book for its honesty & refusal to separate inherent/innate biological behavior with outside environmental forces that collectively shape individuals and make human beings the varied yet homogenous species that it is--as opposed to many sociologists & biologists (in all their varying categories & sub-specialties) that insist on separating several human behaviors/characteristics as merely the product of nature (genes) on one side, or nurture (culture, society, & environment while growing up to adulthood) on the other. Engrossing book that suffers a bit from dry writing.

Ridley gives many interesting examples and counterexamples of how reproduction works in different species in the animal kingdom. Water fleas are all females, but pop out a male every few generations. Fungi have dozens of different genders. Strawberries and corals spread clones in the surrounding area, but produce sexual seeds which are carried away. Elms and oysters produce millions of young to escape their saturated living space. Testicle size in all species corresponds to the level of polygamy observed in the species.He ties it all back to our own behavior and attractions. Sexual selection is the idea that we all have traits that were attractive to ancestors in the past. Even basic human cleverness and communication skills can be explained this way. "One is conscious of what is possible to report to others".In consideration of what forms our criteria for attraction, he proposes an unethical experiment. 1 population is kept ignorant of the opposite gender so that their existence comes as a suprise. Another population is exposed to imagery of hideous/obese people admiring each other and reviling the attractive. What will each group ultimately find attractive?Overall this book is an enjoyable overview of the evolution of thought on the subject over the last few decades.

Not to be confused with Drabble's novel, this non-fiction is all about your genes. Loved it! If you think it's not all about sex, you're mistaken. Your sex genes, as are all animals', are evolving as fast as any other gene in your body and they are in strong competition with others' sex genes that are all striving to make it into future generations. All animals are subject to gene competition, but who knew that males and females are in competition with each other the second they begin courtship! The title of the book, The Red Queen, refers to the evolutionary hypothesis (taken from Lewis Carol's chess piece in Through the Looking Glass) regarding how genes compete so well with each other that they end up back at the starting line (the same place) to continue competing. As the parasite gets stronger, the animals protective "lock" against that parasite gets more clever (evolves) and neither is really ahead of the other as they both struggle to adapt best for the future environment. Animals are still in a race against parasite and Organisms' sex genes are still in a competition with each other, which helps explain much of animal behavior and some of that other animal's behavior - humans.

First 200 or so pages are as precise a representation of the field as one can get with many added facts on the actual "Red Queen" theory. It's very informative and does a good job of really getting at the roots of each theory. Lots of pros and cons as well as he explains his reasoning. He's a pretty clear author.As I've started to notice with many academic books, there comes a point when the author becomes increasingly interested in making conjectures about future work. These sections tend to be heavier on opinion. Some of those opinions I didn't like so much, like his small example of blondes near Stockholm and his tangent about the gay gene. I think this was just a bit too controversial for me and displays my own ability to be open about these theories. Maybe also, it displays my natural tendency to prefer those theories that are well established. The undertone might have not been to my liking.Other than that, it's a good book. Better than most of the books that get into the theories mentioned. Red Queen itself is something that many books don't really address well enough.What you'll notice in this genre is that the major theories tend to repeat themselves. So a lot of the book was stuff I had read before.

Following quote in the last chapter basically sums this book up perfectly:"Just as Mercator could not get the relative sizes of Europe and Africa correct until he had the perspective that longitude and latitude provided, so is the perspective of other animals vital to the study of human nature. It is impossible to understand the social life of a phalarope or a sage grouse or an elephant seal or a chimpanzee in isolation. You can describe each in glorious detail of course: they are respectively polyandrous, lekking, harem-defending, fission-fusion. But only with the perspective of evolution can you truly understand why. Only then can you see the part that different opportunities for parental investment, different habitats, different diets, and different historical baggage have played in determining their natures. It is the purest nonsense to abandon the perspective of comparison with other animals just because of our hubristic belief that humans alone are learning creatures that re-invent themselves at whim."Don't let the first half of the book deter you (as the author admits, it gets deep in the weeds on microbiology and genetics...thus my 4 stars). Second half is a read that will shed much needed light on who we are as humans, and how we got this way.

Very interesting read. Basically how sexual selectivity has driven human instincts and evolution (i.e. bigger brains, universal mate preferences, etc.). One theory is how big brains are a competitive tool against other humans, since there is no fiercer competition than within your species. Also, that big brains were meant primarily for social purposes (i.e. judging character and intents of other people, building alliances/hierarchy) and for seduction (through charm, wit, eloquence, inventiveness) of the other sex. Red Queen theory refers to the fact that evolution is like a treadmill--every advantage eventually becomes "normalized" bringing every party back to where it was initially, e.g. immunity against one parasite leads to an advantage to that parasite, but then the parasite with the genes to counteract that immunity will rise to prominence, eventually eliminating the initial advantage of genes with that immunity. You see the same thing play out across evolution among all species and life forms. Definitely puts one in a more competitive mindset...Unlike a lot of "fluffy" mass market science books, Matt Ridley keeps things academic and logically rigorous where the book needs to be, and yet still manages to keep things interesting and entertaining. A great science writer!

This is a very enjoyable read full of surprising questions and answers. Who knew there were so many ways to replicate, even sexually?Matt Ridley is clearly not a blank slater. In chapters 8, 9, and 10 and elsewhere he argues against blank slate dogma better than Steven Pinker did in his book The Blank Slate. I keep encountering evidence that that dogma is alive and well. Recently on National Public Radio a woman being interviewed took the view that girls simply must be as good at math as boys, therefore the data must have been skewed in studies that show otherwise. And, besides, she herself was exposed to language before she was exposed to math, so naturally she is better at language. I don't care if this woman is brilliant; she is clearly engaging in motivated reasoning and confirmation bias; she's twisting the facts to fit her conclusion.So what is it that made us human, and especially intriguing, what gave us our big heads--and everything that term implies? Maybe it was sexual selection. Maybe it was parasites (Parasite Rex by Carl Zimmer). Maybe it was cooking (Catching Fire: How Cooking Made Us Human by Richard Wrangham). Maybe it was a combination of those and other factors still to be discovered.

[The animal world is not uniform when you have a closer look: sexual reproduction, asexual reproduction, natural cloning (?), hermophrodism, fertilization of egg by egg, variety of sexual chromosomes and chromosome's inheritance (ex. birds vs humans), unfertilized eggs leading to an organism, sex predisposition due to temperature and nutrition factors, genetic selection by females, varying factors of attraction among the species (in birds -- males are ornamented, in humans -- women take more care of their appearances), most of birds are monogamous, animals -polygamous, correlation between size of testicles and fidelity (larger testicles - polygamy, smaller - monogamy), chimpanzee - larger than human's testicles, gorilla - smaller than human's testicles, male humans had larger testicles in the past (selective breeding decreased the size due to monogamy), male humans produce kamikaze spermatozoids that block the entrance of vagina for better chances of fertilization, in female humans fertile cycles are indicated by temperature change (no visual signs), some apes have visual signs when females are fertile, ...And then comes a talk about male/female brain differences and stereotypical gender behaviors...]

Excellent and thought-provoking book with interesting hypotheses -Our large brains evolved specifically because of sexual selection. Men and women needed to be wittier and more charismatic to attract mates, the wittiest and most charismatic had larger brains and produced more children. This selective pressure works in the same way that a peacock's tail feathers get larger and larger. Peahen's are attracted to the large tail feathers and each generation has larger and larger tail feathers despite these tail feathers becoming a handicap to the peacock.We age more slowly and live longer than other apes because men are attracted to younger looking women who will bear them more children. The people who age more slowly produce more children than those who age quickly, so each generation ages more slowly and is younger looking, as the neotony genes are passed on.There is a 0 per cent correlation in IQ for adopted children raised together. In other words, a shared environment has no effect on intelligence, whereas something like 50% of intelligence comes from genes, another 15% from the womb, another 15% from a good education and 20% from other sources.

Ridley gives a very comprehensive analysis of his journalistic endeavor to examine as many aspects of human sexuality and its link to evolutionary selection as possible. Using dozens of fascinating examples from the animal and plant kingdoms he uses these broad frames of reference to search for answers to why humans select sexual partners. It's more complex than the simple transfer of genes from one generation to the next. It has as much to do with keeping pace with our main competitors; parasites via selection of disease free partners, as it has to do with intellectual stimulation or novelty.Of course some of Ridley's examples are outdated, like the fact that there is no genetic disposition towards aggression, but he addresses this in his conclusion that he will probably be proven wrong as the science continues to prove new hypotheses.A very interesting read that not only looks at sex and evolution but as the title says it also includes the ongoing continuing and intriguing debates about nature vs nurture and cooperation vs competition. Ridley leaves these as evenly weighted arguments and does not end up favoring one over another

I have read a number of Matt Ridley's books and find a lot of the points he makes very interesting, if given the option I'd rate this book about 3.75 rather than 4. I found some of his points quite difficult to swallow, in particular when it comes to gender roles and gender vs. sexuality. However, just because I was uncomfortable with them doesn't necessarily make me right. I also appreciate books that look at the human species as what it is - an animal species with animal instincts, trying to understand it and how it works in complex human societies.I do think that some of his arguments could do with more evidence and some expansion on theories that Ridley himself may not necessarily agree with (which I felt he did well at the beginning of the book but not so well towards the end). Although I didn't agree with everything he said it has made me keen to go out and look for more theories and evidence myself which I think it a good outcome from reading a scientific book. I would also be interested to see if any of the author's view have changed with over two more decades of research into the subject of human sexuality available.

This book, as many other reviewers pointed out, is one you have to fight your way into to get to the good stuff. I am fascinated by so-called 'human nature' and why there is the need to somehow separate our species from the rest of the animal kingdom. Ridley has got his feet, like mine, firmly in the camp that acknowledges we are another class of animal. I bought this when I was in a 'women's studies' phase and it led me into other areas that the author has covered. He has many theories that buck the trend; Government is parasitic, global 'warming' is just weather and just recently a blog post, of one of his articles for The Spectator, 'Tobacco denial and pesticide alarm'.I like anything that exists outside of the 'box' and this author is one of them.

A very well researched and thorough book. It was interesting in parts and a bit long winded in others. Upon finishing the book, I still didn't really understand the point the author was trying to make. There was never a clear conclusion but maybe that's how the author intended it to be. I suppose the main message is that everything we do is to leave more children and pass on our genes but yet the author just glosses over people who choose to remain chaste or couples who choose not to have kids. I think the down side about trying to write about human nature is that we have such a strong ability to choose and thereby override any "human nature" that we possess - at least much more so than any other mammal.There was a lot of information about other animals and how sex fits in with their nature. While it's interesting to learn about how other animals are, sometimes you can draw parallels to people and sometimes you can't. Nonetheless, it was interesting to learn about.Not a bad read for anyone who is interested in further understanding people and our motivations.

Fascinating exploration of why sex for reproduction exists, incorporating scientific findings from genetics, sociology, evolutionary development, psychology, and broad biology. While Ridley makes most of the book accessible to the layperson, it clearly is aimed at the educated layperson. That is to say, this is not for the casual reader looking for easy tidbits of knowledge, as this feels further from the popular science side of the bell curve and closer to the academic writing end. As a result, while the book might be slow going and some section warrant reading more than once, the reader comes away with some fairly sophisticated concepts. The book is more than two decades old and it would be nice to see an updated version with newer scientific findings (including epigenetic findings). Nonetheless, much of the content is still relevant, invites deep thought, and disrupts some widely held beliefs (cultural rather than scientific) about sex, males and females, and humans as just another mammal.

I'm conflicted on how to rate this book overall. It certainly has some great ideas but at the same time it's cripplingly incomprehensible at times, and woefully short of explanation when it needs it, and needlessly expansive in other places.Riddley 's clear exploration of the many theories on why sex might have evolved is a great set of chapters. He clearly states the merits and demerits of the important ones, and you're a convert to the theory he believes in (that sex evolved as a mechanism to combat parasites). I found his paragraphs on sexual selection, and polygamy to be heavy going though, for reasons stated above. He finishes with a flourish however when he states that the human brain might be a product of sexual rather than natural selection. I'd picked up this book to read more on this, but it doesn't have too much on the subject. Overall, a good introduction, but the book is too un-rigorously written for my taste.

There are some surprising mistakes in this book. However the interweaving of empirical findings and theoretical debates makes it an excellent summary of the deep questions, the evidence, and the raging battles between the theorists. Why do sexual organisms thrive, when asexual reproduction is so much more efficient? The answer seems to be that sex is a useful mechanism to fight parasites because it "changes the locks" of cellular defense mechanisms (the arms race again) without throwing away the mechanisms that were useful in the past and will be useful again in the future. There is also an elegant discussion of the importance of adultery for understanding the varieties of animal behavior, where the driving force is the variation in the female feeding habits. To think that I used to mock biologists for studying the esoteric variation of mating calls among insignificant animals in remote locations...

Matt Ridley has done an exceptional job in this book to provide insights on Evolution and the role played by Sex in the process. I have read a couple other books, Selfish Gene and Why Evolution Is True on the topic of evolution but the perspective taken by Matt is unique and remarkable.The book can be vaguely divided into two parts. The first part talks about what sexual selection is and how sexual reproduction happens. There's a deep dive that talks about Meiosis mentioning Recombination and Outcrossing. This information is crucial to understanding many of the concepts in the book.The second part of the book is about how two genders of the same species differ and the reason for those differences - just as the title says 'Sex and the Evolution of Human Nature'.Chapters 6 and 7 are truly interesting and talk about polygamy in men and monogamy in women. "Polygamy and 3-D spatial skills seem to go together in several species." - Brilliant!Witty and kept me curious till the end.

"Half the ideas in this book are probably wrong. ... But as long as we can keep asking why, we have a noble purpose." - RidleyI feel like I deserve a phd for completing this tome! Fascinating. I'm a layperson, but even I was amused at how efficiently and persuasively Ridley presents and subsequently discredits so many complex scientific theories and studies. It's clean and well done...like watching a magician with a deck of cards. Look - see this person's lifelong thesis? Poof. It's gone. Some of his reasoning is questionable (and dated now) but he sure tells an entertaining story!I just love the quote I posted above, which offers him an out (even though it's at the very end of this authoritative manifesto and rings with false humility).The first half is biology 101 and interesting background...but it sure makes for a loooong book. The "juicy" human stuff comes later. This is science-lite - perfect for me - but it required some patience to complete.

The need to persist in the investigation of any topic referred to as 'settled science' resonates throughout this work. While the book itself, beautifully read by Simon Prebble, was an insightful discussion covering the critical role of sex, selectivity and evolution one of the most rapt discussions occurred at the end. Within the last few moments the author humbly acknowledges that at least "50% of this book is probably wrong." He cites fad-ish themes from the past which all had their moment as 'settled science' all of which have now faded into curious waypoints in the history of human thought. Galton's Eugenics, Freud's consciousness, Durkheim's sociology, Mead's culture driven anthropology, Skinner's Behaviorism, Wilson's Sociobiology and Piaget's early learning have, through the proper application of the scientific method of inquiry and research, dropped from the list of popular wisdoms.

This book is a "trust me it comes together in the end" type of books. When I picked up this book, I was intrigued by the "Red Queen" concept and thought it would focus purely on human sex. However, this book will give you such an in-depth understanding of sex (of course), anthropology, psychology, sociology, biology and ethology (or zoology). This book was beautifully written in such a way that the average person can comprehend complex science while the expert scientist can gain something from it. Taking controversial topics such as cheating, polygamy, gender roles, homosexuality and intellectualising it without an political or religious agenda. If you're like me and came here from Niel Strauss' "The Game" - I'll tell you right now that there's nothing in this book that you can say to someone that will encourage them to sleep with you. However, if you're a man, it will greatly help you to understand women. If you're a women, it will greatly help you to understand men.

This is an absolute MUST READ for anyone interested in biology, evolution, psychology, understanding why we have marriages and sex and the way we think about it. Absolutely. Brilliant. You can also tell that he's a real scientist writing this book because at the end he says "half the ideas in this book are probably wrong" meaning he knows and admits in the ending chapter that we really don't know a lot of things and all the theories in the book discussed aren't 100%, but make some really amazing arguments.Heads up: if you've no background in evolutionary psychology, ecology or any upper level biology studies or haven't read the Selfish Gene by Richard Dawkins, this book may be a little too much for the average reader... So I would highly suggest at least reading the selfish gene to get a good understanding of the first half the book's topics as it relates to genetics and sex. Must. Read. <3.

A great mix of explicable science, humor, adventurousness and theory. Suggested read for any person interested in human behavior and mind/body! You might be as surprised as I was at times. I really admire the humbleness of the author. He states from the beginning that the ideas are not all his, it`s a collection of many different opinions put together by him. At the end he even suggests that they might be plain wrong because, well, who knows? I haven`t read that many science books that heavily emphasis research, experiments and documenting, thus I could easily have swallowed whatever evidence he presented. Ridley brings numerous correlations and indications to each case and debates thoroughly with previous and existing theories in all of the themes he mentions. This leaves me both curious and hungry for more and (as any good book should do, fiction or non-fiction) in contemplation of what I think might be right or wrong about the subject.
A comprehensive exploration of the role of sex in evolution

Started out great - with biological and genetic discussion and evidence of Red Queen theory. Thought provoking analysis and scientific inquiry supported the author's perspective, right up to the point where the focus of the book changed from biology to behavior. The author continued to argue that human behavior is biologically based, but the Red Queen scientific inquiry was lost in this part. Ridley stuck to his position that the Red Queen is working through human behavior, and while this is an interesting interpretation, I found this part of the book less and less interesting. While I agree with many of his assertions and interpretations in the latter part of the work, I did not find the final section scientifically based, and therefore, not as interesting as the first two thirds. Overall, I think it's a "must read" and opens my eyes to Red Queen theory.

Despite being over 15 years old by the time I read it, it holds up well compared to more recent books covering similar ground. This is a testament of the author's insights and logical rigor. It goes deeper into the genetic mechanisms at play in evolution than I had read before so that part was quite interesting. The writing style is comfortably authoritative and witty. While it gives a great basis for the arguments that led to new theories on human sexuality, much of the conclusions are more deeply explored in more recent books such as A Billion Wicked Thoughts (although A Billion Wicked Thoughts possesses less scientific caution than Ridley exhibited, in my opinion).

I've listened to the audiobook of this book. Overall, a very solid research type read on a matter of sex, evolution and purpose of human kind. Life and sex could barely be more technical as it is after reading, fully realizing and living by the thoughts laid down in this book, though it is pretty hard thing to do in reality. Please note that the first half of the book concentrates on a quite peculiar topic of evolutionary fight, whereas the second one emphasizes more of an empirical and, thus, practical, human-like approach to the same phenomena, therefore, it is much faster paced and more enjoyable. It appears life is not that complicated after all, although the correct balance between the importance between 'nature' and 'nurture' is a matter of discussion, which is fascinating for me.Would recommend almost to anybody interested in psychology.

Though informative, I feel as though this book fell short of addressing what it promised to. The Red Queen failed to address anything that would distinguish it from the material covered in a high school biology class. The revelatory points of several chapters (the majority) were comprised of information that really, was already fairly common knowledge. Furthermore, the information that built up to these points was often needlessly complicated. Taking the side of an argument disproved in antiquity is not necessary to maintain an unbiased narrative. I also felt as though the author's narrative style was far too personal for this particular genre of literature- and that the nuances of human sexuality were glossed over to befit simpler theories of evolution. This book is a solid three stars, it is soundly written and accurate (as far as I can tell) but it does not push any boundaries.

Why sex? Why are there "boys" and "girls"? If you look at life from the genes point of view, it will copy itself with 100% efficiency by cloning itself, but most animals and many plants have 50% efficiency by sharing reproduction with a member of the opposite sex. This book argues its way out of this problem by reflecting on the work by leading evolutionary biologists over the past 8 decades (begining with Fisher). The thrust of the argument: genetic diversity is butressed by sex and thus increases "evolvability" to new threats. From the genes point of view (except for the SDF gene on the Y chromosome) each gene travels through generations of boys and girls, ultimatley replicating itself better due to improved resistance.

Overall, the Red Queen is a great introduction (and coverage) of the Red Queen hypothesis in evolutionary biology/sociology. Ridley uses examples, research, and plain english to describe what others are unable to put in [understandable] words. At times, he's a bit too loquacious. One story is enough to pound home an idea. And the theory itself is a tad depressing, and discredits (or rather, forgets) any tenderness or love that works into the equation of reproduction. I suppose reproduction on a micro-level is far more romantic than macro-level analysis. Anyhow, for non-academics, The Red Queen is a perfect text book for understanding evolutionary theory in the context of how we live our every day lives.

Writing in 1993, Matt Ridley argues that much of human nature has been determined by the struggle of our genes to perpetuate themselves, in a never-ending contest against bacteria, parasites, and other humans. The analogy of the Red Queen comes from Alice in Wonderland, where the red queen had to keep running constantly to stay in the same place. Ridley summarizes the current state of knowledge and speculation at the time he wrote, quoting scientists in many fields. And he uses numberous examples of plants and animals to explain and/or to support his argument. The book is dense, but written for the layperson. I wish it were possible to get a short "since-1993" update, to learn what light current scientific research has shed on the issues Ridley discusses.

I read this book about the same time I was reading the Selfish Gene and it was a great companion book. Ridley seems to fully accept the selfish gene theory and uses that as one of his basis for the idea of evolution. I preferred this book over Dawkins book, Ridley is a far better writer and the book focused less on the concept and more on explaining things using good analogies and tons of scientific studies (and open ended speculation). I also really liked that right from the beginning Ridley doesn't attempt to spend any time arguing with creationists, it makes the book far better because I don't have to read the same creationist stuff again and again which seems to be a problem with so many evolution books. I think anyone interested in evolution and biology should pick up this book.

Meandering and unfocused for most of the book, but the last chapter brings the book together nicely. Main point of the book: sexual selection by humans has provided a much more significant evolutionary pressure than external conditions (e.g., weather, food supply, etc.). That is, men and women have been "dog-breeding" each other for 300,000 years. Women have selected traits in men they (women) desire and these traits have become more pronounced over time - much like the peahen's desires affected the evolution of the peacock's tail (i.e., made the tail extravagant, even to the point were it became a threat to the survival of the peacock for being too showy and thus attracting predators). The same holds true for men selecting traits in women. Very enlightening read.

Full of all sorts of ideas about sexual selection and why so many forms of evolution are a Red Queen's race: primarily any predator-prey/host-parasite relations and any within-the-species conflict for limited resources, especially sex.Asks great fundamental questions that I as a non-biologist certainly never think of, like "Why sexual vs. asexual?" or "Why precisely two sexes?" or "Why two different sexes, instead of all hermaphrodites?" and gives the either the authoritative answer where it exists, or the author's best-guess answer to each.One minor frustration: This was a book from the early 1990s, and I'd like to know for some of the author's guesses were right or wrong.I had no idea what an important factor in our evolution the microorganisms living inside us are.

An excellent book on how and why evolution led us to require sex for reproduction and how this has shaped us as humans. This is a book Dawkins mentioned that he wished he himself had written and definitely fills in many gaps. Ridley illustrates everything with examples from various species. Itâs fascinating to see how evolution took different species on very different paths to reproduction. Ridley shines light on our sexual nature as humans, explaining in evolutionary terms why we are attracted to beauty, the relationship between men and woman, marriage and adultery and much more. Even an interesting theory as to why men prefer sons in one society and daughters in another.Overall a very enjoyable read though some early chapters get too scientific and laden with new technical terms.

The author did a great job in his theories by backing up with many studies and literature. However the basal level of human existence is very infuriating at times in this book only because the start of human existence was ruled by our genes and hardly any societal impact by our ancestors. Though it could be true, it was a little hard for me to digest the idea that men favor polygamous relationships because it is one way to offset the cost of male existence by having as many children as possible! Overall a good book and one that can either make you more frustrated with this innate level of human existence or make you more curious that we ever lived that way to describe why we live the way we do now.

As a "scientific book" this was overall quite disappointing. A very promising start to the answers of evolution that sadly digresses into loose science and wide assumption. Interesting case studies from different species, but unfortunately the chapter summaries often missed the point of the central theme. I felt more could've be written about Zahavi's handicap principle and Fisher's sexy sons rather than touching upon them very briefly. Many of the articles referring to human gender-based preferences in the last chapters of the book are known to be methodologically flawed (see: Delusions of Gender by Cordelia Fine) and I felt weren't necessary or totally applicable to explain the point of Red Queen.

This book took me almost a year to read! It gets pretty dense and boring, particularly in the middle section. However, I'm glad I stuck with it because the author does an excellent job of outlining how sexual reproduction is generally superior to asexual reproduction, and how that fits in to the evolutionary arms race.In the last few chapters the author asserts that humans are essentially peacocks and peahens when it comes to sexual selection, except our big brains are the peacock's tail feathers. Thought provoking to be sure, however it does bring up a lot of depressing issues. Do we really have free will or are we just robots being driven by our genes? I see why Richard Dawkins likes this book so much.

While reading this book there were several times I wanted to like get up and fight the author. He makes a lot of heavily stereotyped, not pc statements that are not always scientifically grounded. But I guess that's why he apologizes over and over again, reminding us each chapter that he's not trying to prove what is morally correct but what could have happened.A lot of this book seems just to be a series of hypotheses that aren't super testable based off of what has been observed in nature. They could make logical sense and could work but they are just conjectures based off of a few case studies. But isn't that just how it because when asking "why" instead of "how"--the author is trying to look for history from the present.But I will give him that he is remarkably thorough.

I read this book thanks to Blinkist.The key message in this book:Sex is central to human civilizations, and for good reason. It ensures genetic diversity, protects us from parasites and even accounts for our tremendous intelligence. In these ways and many more, sexual attraction among humans is a key driver of evolution.Suggested further reading: The Evolution of Everything by Matt RidleyThe Evolution of Everything (2015) argues that the phenomenon of evolution â gradual change without goal or end â reaches far beyond genetics. Evolution happens all around us in economic markets, our language, technology and customs, and is whatâs behind nearly all changes that occur in these fields.

I found this book fascinating. You know, if you believe in evolution and other cwazy theories like that. Really interesting stuff about sexual selection throughout biological history. Turns out sexual selection, i.e. genders' preferences for their mates for various reasons, has shaped who we have become almost more so than who didn't get killed by stuff (natural selection). Helped me rest easier knowing many facets of my personality I struggle with are biological in origin... jealousy, competitiveness, attraction. Easy to read, Mr. Ridley has an excellent grasp on how to draw the reader in and build upon ideas despite it being a 'science book.' Highly recommended.

Wow is there a lot that goes on in this book! It could almost be used as an educational text, except that it's fairly outdated now. I still found it to be incredibly informative, and would recommend it to anyone who is interested in learning more about human nature, and the sexuality of humans and nature in general. The way Ridley incorporates the sexuality variances of different species to make his point keeps things interesting. His writing style keeps the subject matter engaging. Ridley seems to have done an incredible amount of research before writing this book, as he appears to have covered all his bases and addressed a lot of other research from the related fields.

Ridley offers a very interesting take on the evolution of human psychology and survival. The main premise is essentially that sex has been the main factor in spurring all forms of human development, from the arts to technology, Ridley argues that sex is the root from which our modern society has been born. This is a must read for anyone interested in evolutionary psychology. For the average reader, this work might be too heavy with academic buzz words. Ridley's voice also comes off a bit pompous and didactic, presenting his studies as the end all of all end alls to answering every question of human existence.

A very interesting book. The author tries to weave together a cohesive theory that explains the why of sex and how the evolution of humans has been deeply influenced by sex. The book is almost 20 years old and so some of the ideas, like men and women having different brains and skill sets, were not entirely foreign to me. The first part of the book focus' on genetics and the author does well in attempting to explain scientific themes to the average person, though I must admit I was lucky if I understood two thirds of this information. Still, it is a very enjoyable read with many interesting ideas.

A pretty academic look at evolution, why we have sex, a thorough and critical look at many of the theories of natural and sexual selectiveness and the positing of a theory why we developed big brains and are relatively "juvenile" for such a long period of time compared to other mammals. The book is a bit dry and it was struggle to get into. But the content, theories and conclusins are fascinating. The book is now nearly 20 years old so I can't speak to the development of current knowledge or thinking on the subject since, but i will probably seek out more books on he subject.It contradicts the recent book I read -- Sex at Dawn -- in some critical respects.

Social habits in animals, is it a product of nature or nurture? This book goes on about differing evolved traits in animals for 3/4 of the book, then the last chapters are all about human evolution, specifically attraction. A lot of lucid metaphors contained in this book comparing human behavior to all different types of animal interactions. In the end it concludes eloquently how a peacock evolved bright plumage to attract, humans evolved complex and ever growing brains. This lead to advanced attractors not present in any other animal. The 4 are "Sense of humor, intellect, creativity and interesting personality."

The book discusses many very interesting questions: what is the evolutionary benefit from sexual reproduction as compared to asexual reproduction, why are there exactly 2 genders and not 3, why do men fall for younger women, ... The reasons are not always easy to understand.I believe the book contains a few logical mistakes. For example, "By ceasing to breed once they have a boy, which those interested in dynastic succession might do, people would have male biased sex ratios."This is incorrect, the probability of having a boy/girl doesn't depend on the gender of the first child, so this does not impact the ratio males to females.Overall, highly interesting book!

Just a little warning. This book can leave you in deep depression, as you'll realize you are just a product of evolution that happened to be conscious (so it can deceive fellow human and attract mates).On the other hand, Matt Ridley knows how to write an easy to follow book. He will take you on a journey through evolution of different views on evolution. He will describe and defend one theory, just to disprove it on next page, offering another theory in place. This process can have multiple iterations, arriving to something that makes most sense. Thanks to this special writing style, you'll make your own opinions a resonate with some views more than others.

The book starts off somewhat slow - I have to admit the parasite theory did bore me a bit. It becomes better towards the end, though. My favorite chapters (and frankly, the main motivation for me to read this book) are the gender wars and beauty chapters. This sphere of evolution sparkled my attention already in Dawkins' immortal classics - "the Selfish Gene".If you felt like you wanted to know more about underlying forces that shape the relationship between men and women in their more simplistic form, this book will give you a food for thought. Insight on hormone functioning of the organism was also very interesting.

I was happily surprised by this book. I used to work in a sexual-selection lab and so I find this kind of thing quite interesting. However, this book was written in 1993 and I expected it to be... cringe-worthy on certain topics. But it wasn't! He did a good job at explaining that "natural" or "selected for" means nothing about whether or not it should be allowed in society - without coming across as trying to cover his ass by being politically correct. Overall, well researched and well written: a very cohesive book.I would recommend this book to biologists and critical thinkers - I'm sure there are many things that could be taken out of context in this book.

A rundown of most of the common arguments and characteristics of sexual selection and genetics in animals in general, this book then delves deeper into the implications for humans in particular. Of the first few chapters, the most interesting were the ones explaining where sex and gender came from in the first place; why we aren't all hermaphrodites or of thousands of genders, which seems like a better evolutionary strategy. The explanations of human behavior are interesting, but we seem to only be able to explain human *sexual* behavior by sexual selection; the arguments for spatial reasoning et cetera remain unconvincing.

This is not a book about biology. It's a book about philosophy. I see the "red queen" concept everywhere. Business, marketing, investing, jokes, everything. Pop up ads. When they started in the early 2000s. People clicked on them. Same for "You've WON!" Ads with flashing yellow and red text. Now, who clicks on pop ups? Noone. Marketing and scammy ads have moved on. The world appears to move forward by leaps and bounds, but in many senses we are in exactly the same place. Not exactly the most profound realization, but an important one to me nonetheless. Change and innovation are constant necessities for a fruitful life.

Darwin's theory of natural selection opened a can of worms. Matt Ridley adds to the support for the case by attempting to explain: Why sexual and not asexual reproduction? Why males and females? Why do some species switch sexes? Why is human behavior around sex so peculiar?The arguments are well composed and organized to build the case. I thoroughly enjoyed reading it. I especially enjoyed how others were interested in borrowing the book to read it themselves.

Ever wonder why, as a species have sex? Ever wonder why you were attracted to certain physiological features?Rare is the book that can breech a subject like biology (more specifically genetics) and keep things interesting, much less be outstandingly funny/insightful. The author walks you through everything at the perfect pace. If you are a genetics student of if you've just had a few high school biology classes you will have no trouble following along with the discussion.This book presents some amazing ideas backed up with scientific research.

Pretty good. It's a bit old as far as science goes (mid-nineties) but still has some interesting insights about animal and human nature. If you're in it for the human insights, as I was, you might be put off by the first 40% of the book, which is all non-human. If you persist, it will be worth it, and Ridley does build on the part about humans what he talked about with, you know, all them other critters, but if you're impatient then by all means skip the parts about birds and slugs and bacteria and get right to the fun stuff.

I really enjoyed this book. As a scientific non-fiction read it's definitely not for everyone.To be honest, it's not for most people. But if you're the kind of person what would enjoy finding out things like:* Why do humans reproduce sexually instead of asexually?* Is there a biological reason why men value attractiveness in a potential mate more than women do? (spoiler: yes)* Are polygamy laws to protect women or to protect men? (you might be surprised)then I *highly* recommend this book.

A wider-ranging tome than the title promises.... the initial question (why do we reproduce sexually, when asexual reproduction is so much more efficient?) is disposed of in the early chapters.Ridley then spends 400 pages investigating the ins and outs of sexual selection across a variety of organisms. The last few chapters are dedicated to human evolution, especially mate selection strategies, inheritance customs, and the tremendous expansion of the human braincase.I always enjoy Ridley's work. This one is not my favorite, but it was an informative, interesting read.

This was a fabulous book. Ridley did a fantastic job synthesizing a vast number of scientific studies on a variety of topics relating to sex and sexual selection to make a relevant and cohesive argument about human evolution. I highly recommend this to anyone who has ever asked questions about why human males and females behave differently or about why our brains are so large or why gossip is so incredibly interesting. The Red Queen is a fantastic read and I think it will interest anyone with an open mind.

Read for my biology class, this book concisely states the general theory of why sex happens. The Red Queen is a theory that is explained by a passage from Lewis Carroll's Alice Through the Looking Glass "Now, here, you see, it takes all the running you can do, to keep in the same place." This theory simply explains the hypothesis that evolution is necessary for an organism and its parasites to remain at a constant stalemate. A good example was that of bacteria evolving resistance to antibacterials.

The author is at his best when he constantly asks "why?" on issues that may seem mundane or which we take for granted. Why sex not asex? Why does our concept of beauty take on its current form? Why are we mostly monogamous? How has sexual selection shaped out intelligence? My only gripes about this thought provoking read are that it's about a decade old (painfully obvious by the incorrect statistics on the human genome) and Ridley sometimes overstates his conclusions for the sake of the lay audience.

Matt Ridley is a brilliant science writer. He has chronicled the human genome project and written a biography of Francis Crick. Both were excellent insights into the world of the gene, and this work exceeds both of them. From the origins of sexual reproduction to why men treat a woman's vagina as their property, from evolutionary sexual selection to the psychology of sexual behavior, this book is a brilliant insight into the evolution of the genome by sexual reproduction. This is a great book for fans of biology and those with more than rudimentary knowledge as well.

An engaging read which not only espouses it's own position, but gives you the history of the various debates contained within. The theories are presented as true until the author points out what is wrong with them, which you might have been able to infer, or not, from reading them yourself. This makes the book a highly gratifying read and creates more than one line of dialogue between you and the book. The author is also wise and has a great deal of common sense and charisma, which makes this very academic book seem not at all like the typically dry academic read.

The book The Red Queen purports to explain a number of observed facts related to sex by gathering together diverse opinions by different scientists. Many of the explanations chosen by the author seem actually very plausible while others not as much. I particularly liked the red queen metaphor about the reason why there is sex. However, the reasons given as to why there are two sexes or why humans have large brains don't seem very convincing. Overall, The Red Queen has lots of interesting facts that make it a very informative and enjoyable book.

Fascinating book. The author justifies using examples from the animal kingdom to illustrate examples, and I wouldn't argue with that logic, since we are part of the animal kingdom. However, it made reading the majority of the book slow and feel "irrelevant" to human. The "human nature" part of the book is tucked away near the end and felt like it could be explored in more depth, and sooner.As far as a book explaining the tie between sexual reproduction and the "red queen" argument, it did an excellent job. It lost 2 stars for avoiding the human part of its title.

Sex (the exchange of genetic material) is our way of staying one step ahead of parasites that are constantly evolving to attack our species.Human sexuality itself is quite complex, mostly because child bearing is an expensive task for humans.Men, for whom child bearing is inexpensive, prefer polygamy. They select mates based on evidence of health and youth.Women, for whom child bearing is expensive, prefer monogamy. They desire mates to have good genes (represented as height, health, etc) as well as the ability to provide for her offspring (represented as status, power, etc).

I had fun reading this, but I'm a sucker for genetics and evolution so it barely counts. I think it's a great introductory book to a lot of different topics, and even though there were chapters that I wanted badly to skim, most of the book is light and entertaining. As the author repeatedly says, most of the theories and explanations in this book are probably wrong or incomplete or not good enough, but it leaves a lot of place for imagination and/or investigation, so I guess as a reader one can greatly benefit from reading this book, if you're into that sort of things.

This felt like it took me forever to get through, and I definitely have some criticisms, particularly of Ridley's tendency to reference things he talked about 100 pages ago without reminding you what they are (and endnotes. Fuck those.) But overall, this was a great book with a lot of interesting science that sparked a lot of discussions in my house. It also made me realize how little I actually know about biology, and how much we don't learn in school. Who knew that fungi have thousands of sexes, but no males? (In that case, what does "male" even mean??)

Excellent science writing on the nature of sexual selection. First few chapters explore the question "Why sex?" That is, what problems does it solve for biology? That out of the way, the book then goes into a discussion of sexual selection in a variety of species, esp. birds, but also various mammals & some fish. Finally begins to explore the impact of sexual selection on humans and human behavior. Final chapter muses (somewhat convincingly) on the possibility that our big brains are mostly just a sexually selected trait in much the same way that the peacock tail is.

I found the speculation on how evolution may impact human nature brilliant. The author mentions the rebuff that the sociobiologists received in the 1970's (I scoffed at that work back then) but delivers good arguments for why the model for human behavior should not be a nature vs nurture but a blended mix of influences from our instincts and learned from our culture. I was pleasantly surprised at the discussion about the great number of instincts we have, included the instinct to learn! I may look into another book by Matt Ridley.

This book by Matt Ridley emphasis the role of sexual selection over natural selection on the evolution of mankind. This book is also, to a small extent, a political call against "political correctness" that hinders mankind knowing more about itself. Matt Ridley is a humble writer who, despite some unavoidable generalisations, writes in the epilogue that "Half the ideas in this book are probably wrong". I think we should follow his world view. I would recommend it to anyone interested in biology (and science in general).

Really thought-provoking, albeit extremist, book about how evolution, especially sexual selection, drives human behavior. He questions that we just take for granted like why don't we just reproduce asexually? (We'd have twice the evolutionary potential) Or why we we get married but then have affairs? Why aren't we just polygamous? What makes a trait "sexy"? Really interesting stuff, although I think a lost a little faith in humanity after reading it.

recommended by lidiai didnt understand all parts of it... i like the way he wrote, but i also thought there were huge chunks that should have been explained better. i dont know much about evolution, and then to have all those theories spun on me... ahh! anyway, parts of it were really good. i mostly focused on the parts on man+woman relationships and why each sex acts the way they do...thanks lid!

no, sex is not just a deep dark inescapable secret none of us wants to talk about.. ridley reaches into the depths human and animal nature, and siezes the very reason and manner of its existence, stripping away all superficial meanings and arriving at the essential core of the dichotomy of gender. how far does sex permeate the very character of our physical, emotional, and mental experience? read it and find out.

My advisor gave me this book over ten years ago. It took me so long to read because many of the theories in the book have become almost common knowledge in evolutionary biology. However once I picked it up I found it a concise review of how sexual selection (may) have influenced human evolution. This book is aimed at the general public and is an easy and informative read. One other thing to note is that much of the science is still relevant after 15 years.

Although it was not particularly well organized, and some of the more complex theories were not made entirely clear, this was a very enjoyable and enlightening exploration of evolutionary biology. While still amazed by the idea of examining human society with the tools of evolutionary biology, it is interesting how many basic questions are still unanswerable, such as: why are there homosexuals? Or: why do we have such big brains?

This is the kind of book that I read when I was 14-15 and fascinated by evolution and human evolution especially. It was fun to go back and read a new book that addressed a lot of those themes, while at the same time adding things that I either don't remember or weren't present in the books I read back then. This was a good look, in my opinion, at the different viewpoints on evolution and how it happened (and why it happened).

To not give this book 5 star is a crime, by god or beastly. No job's done for i was busy reading. Every page made me a smarter man, or at least the way I feel. For those who sat beside me on a train, seeing me read this book and not asking - What's it about? - and then not reading it; he is a fool.For sure my life is short; maybe today, tomorrow or in twenty years to come my time to go. For the few books a man have read, for this is the few at least a man must read.

I really liked it. Good overview of the development of sex and the reasons for it, even if it did seem a little more confident in its conclusions than could be warranted. I imagine it would also get critisism from some quarters for suggesting that there are evolutionary reasons for differences between make and female behaviour in other species and we have no scientific reason for saying this can't be the same in humans.

Packed with new information, many examples, clever ideas - it was delight to read each day on my way to work. The evolution processes are much more complex than we could ever imagine - propelled by the Red Queen phenomenon. Despite the fact our brains have not been designed to understand fully their own evolution but it is nice keep trying to learn more and more about it - and this is so awesome, the never ending story of science!

Really interesting look at the evolution of sexual reproduction in general and the ways it has influenced human nature. One thing I really liked was that Ridley didn't have an agenda; he presented the prevailing hypotheses on each topic then discussed the evidence for and against each one. I'm curious to know where things stand now as this book was published in 1993. Fascinating subject and I learned a lot.

An evolutionary perspective on sex, mating, beauty and other pieces of human nature. Inspires to think about the deep reasons for our desires and behavior. Also the idea of the red queen (constant conflict which spurs evolution but doesn't give any side a hude advantage) can be imaginativly applied to other systems. I'm happy i was introduced to this perspective and i think i need to strengthen my understanding of it with other books. Someone recommended me to read Steve Pinker.

Well written and insightful. It doesn't talk down or gloss over facts and figures, but unlike my last few reads it doesn't read like a thesis. I'll leave with an excerpt from the end of the book," I sometimes feel that we are fated to never understand ourselves because part of our own nature is to turn every inquiry into an expression of our own nature: ambitious, illogical, manipulative and religious."

Interesting Unromantic View of HumanityThe book JSA beautiful,thought provoking essay on Human Nature with ought being Romantic ,meaning not taking out the animal nature of humanity. The book argues that while we have been running in place trying to evolve faster than nature, it is our ability to deceive one another that has allowed us to survive. I know that sentence does not make sense, but if you read the book it would.

It's hard for me to imagine a Matt Ridley book I wouldn't like... This one was different than 'Genome' for me because it took one hypothesis (The Red Queen) in depth. Therefore, it would be harder for the general public to get into and stay with the book because you have to follow a thread of scientific inquiry to completion, but it was so worth it!

Mr. Ridley posits that evolution is like the fictional character The Red Queen, in Lewis Carrol's book Through the Looking Glass. Like this character, a species will "run" in place as fast as they can(adapting to their environments)in order to stay in place(survive to the next generation and pass along their genes). Fascinating read.

the best book in the entire world - better than anything written by any dweebo like Shakespeare or Milton or Poe or Thoreau or whoever the doobs were who faked out the fairy tales in the Bible or Koran or Talmud or whatever other religious crap there is... Also can be used to completely change your understanding of people if you happen to be befuddled by the inane things they do to each other

This book was interesting but really hard for me to follow, and I'm not exactly a dummy. It was, again, text-bookish, but because the subject matter was interesting, I was able to cross the finish line. Its about sexual evolution (biologically speaking, not from the social perspective as much as is necessary.)

Much better than I anticipated- one advantage of having an inanity in bold on the back cover. Poses an interesting explanation for evolution of human brain size- runaway sexual selection, which, for several reasons, is actually more plausible than popular alternative explanations. It also delves into lots of other fascinating topics like the evolution of sex. I highly recommend it.

This book raised some very interesting aspects of our evolution and was a great companion to the Selfish Gene by Richard Dawkings. Matt Ridley continues the argument of the selfish gene with some insightful additions as well as comparisons to competitive/comparative theories. I would highly suggest this book to anyone interested in the origins of the human psyche.

I'm not sure I would agree with everything in this book now, but back when I first read it, it was ironically one of the first times that I seriously started to think about how social and biological phenomena interact to shape the experience of gender. I know, it seems naive now, but, hey everyone's got to start somewhere!

If you've ever wonder why we aren't hermaphrodites, this book explains it perfectly. The author digs deeply into how natural selection operates at the genome level to create macroscopic behaviors with examples from all over the animal kingdom. Lots of good psychological insight into why men and women work the way they do.

This was absolutely fascinating, though the author could have benefited from an editor with sharper eyes and a sense of literary asthetic. Great theories and hypotheses on why our species has two genders, rather than only one or three+ like many species, and why we produce sexually instead of some other way. I liked it.

I have personally purchased many copies of this book just to pass it on to others. I think this is one of the most important works ever written and something that needs to be considered by every intelligent individual around. Ridley is absolutely brilliant, with an excellent grasp of his specialty and I would recommend most of what he's written-- but this one especially.

The book made me want to go back to school and study biology. The title doesn't really give you a feel for the scope of the book--from the asexual reproduction of insects and the occasional lizard to the biological reasons that women are more likely to conceive as the product of an affair, this book will give you all sorts of fascinating factoids.

No doubt this book will offend many, and should only be attempted with an open mind. I found it to be a fasnicating glimpse into the world of human nature and evolutionary psychology, focused mainly on sexual selection. This book is quite scientific, and predicated on how human gender differences are biological, and ultimately deals with our views of gender roles in society.

I just couldn't finish this book. I got about halfway through and was tired of reading about the evolution of bugs, birds and viruses. I might pick it up again someday because I believe the author was setting the stage to discuss these evolutionary principles in humans. I just wish it hadn't taken him half the book to get to that point.

A thought provoking book that takes few liberties. Though dated (for a science book) it provides some extremely interesting insights into human nature, sex, and evolution. It changed the fundamental way I looked at "nature v. nurture" and made me more curious as to what advances have been made in the same direction since the book was written.

This book was certainly interesting. However, it did contain a great deal of information on current research in sexual selection and at times was rather hard to follow. I found the chapter on monogamy/polygamy particularly hard to follow.This is not a bad read but is one you have to concentrate on - not one which you can read while watching telly for example.

Our two biological drives are to survive and reproduce. Sex determines everything and subsequently, manâs evolutionary narrative has unfolded in response to these two imperatives. Well researched, scientifically credible arguments, and very accessible to the layperson. Iâll guarantee youâll look at human interactions and social dynamics a lot differently after reading this book. 4/5

Solid introduction to Evolutionary Biology. Would recommend this to anyone who wants an updated version of the Selfish Gene. I would really like to see an updated edition to this, with current research added to breathe life back into this book. But for someone seeking an introduction to this field, this would be the place to start.

Almost put this book down early on in a fit of undergraduate know-it-all snobbery when Ridley tried to say that the reason why deer all behave in a similar manner while humans divide labor is because we sort our genes sexually. (For the record, so do deer). That would have been a mistake, as this book is superbly reasoned and informative.

I listened to it as an audiobook and read it on my kindle.In terms of a purely factual read, it was fun. If you didn't realize it by the title, it's all about sex. Not in a raunchy or even graphical way but in a sex as a biological drive.Would recommend the audiobook, it was with me on my evening walks and was very easy to listen to.

I love Ridley's wit and straight-forward writing, which is certainly unique in the realm of science. Though I picked this up as a bit of light reading (yes I am that much of a nerd), I enjoyed it more than I expected because it used a lot of real-life examples and simple logical explanations to work through the big genetic question: why sex?

I love this book. It is a review & critique of more theories of why sexual reproduction is an evolutionary advantage than I knew existed. I'm learning a lot about genetics that have happened since I studied it in college (duh!) I'm listening to the audio book, and I sometimes have to rewind to process things - it's not a casual read.

Great overview of the current evolutionary biology/psychology theories.
