Main themes of the book are: sex differences, race differences, sexual selection in humans and animals, selfish gene theory, red queen hypothesis, nature of humans and their similarities with other primates, zahavi handicap principle as well as many others.

[audiobook via audible.com] . . . a fascinating argument -- that sexual selection, and not necessarily natural selection (i.e., choices rather than environmental challenges) may have significantly influenced the homo sapiens brain size, and thus our intellect, wit, creativity, and the ability to influence social groups.

I can't stop raving about this book! It is absolutely relevant in every interaction of life. I found Ridley putting into words what I often hypothesized about animal and human motives. He writes with a wit and a snap that simply illuminates his deep understanding of evolutionary biology. I can't wait to read the rest of his works, as I'm very quickly becoming an evangelist of his writing!!

I jumped around a bit in this book and probably ended up reading only about four fifths of it. But it's the kind of book you can do that with, and I thoroughly enjoyed it. I must say I don't feel I can top Courtney's review of this, so go check it out. In the comments section she gives a more detailed review of the book.

In this fascinating exposÃ©, Matt Ridley provides us a classic introduction to the various provocative and enlightening theories of sexual selection and its nature to human evolution. This book is still relevant today and a highly recommended book in assisting one with the information and analysis in considering the nature of sex and the evolution of human nature.

For the audiobook version. This was wonderful to listen to for a month while I was walking the dog, although I'll admit it was difficult to keep the whole thread of the science actively in my head for the duration of the book. Some of the examples were hilarious, though, and being read by a rather droll English voice made it all the funnier.

The first half of the book was like pulling teeth; I would black out and wake up two pages later with sweat pouring down my face and empty ice cream tubs surrounding my frail, dehydrated body. After 100 pages and 50 tubs of ice cream SHIT GOT GOOD. Very interesting read. Wouldn't recommend if lactose intolerant.

This is a fantastic book. Ridley shares some very provocative thoughts on sex, evolution, and how each of these impact human nature while providing some very interesting details about various species, etc. I think everyone should read the book, mainly to better understand how the Red Queen is ever present in various aspects of life.

Read "Same Difference" by Rosalind C. Barnett.Soo stereotypical. Too many assumptions and generalizations. Evidence seems irrelevant to the argument made, lacking, incorrect or exaggerated. It feels like a poor excuse for cheating, sexism and blatant misogyny.We are individuals. Make your own choices not based on your gender role or someone else's expectations.

Recommended read for anyone interested in life, how it works, evolves. Highlights include:interaction between learned behaviour and genes, behaviour and gender, societal norms and genes, positive and negative feedback loops, psychology and genes. The book is also rich in colourful examples illustrating the concepts, theory and opinions

This book has helped me get rid of my misconceptions about whether humans are instinctual or cultural creatures, and also understand risk seeking and dominance in us men. Those are the first things from the top of my head, but there are so many more great and terrible I've learned about the human race, and about animals, from this book. I'm also going to re-read it for some in depth analysis.

How humans, as well as some other species, use sex to evolve. Fascinating explanation of many a phenomena in human biology, psychology and sociology based on sex. Definitely recommend to anyone who's interested in "how stuff works"! It's somewhat difficult to get through some of the "boring" stuff, but circa page 120 it gets so interesting it's hard to put down.

Great book for anyone who is curious about human sexuality. The first half of the book was more about different species of animals and their mating habits. However, the second half contained great information about humans and the biological reasoning why we do the things we do when it comes to sex and relationships.

The enlightening product of a relentlessly agile, even acrobatic mind. Ridley's command of the historical background is vast but never intimidating to the intelligent layman, who cannot hope but to have their perspective changed. My only qualm is the point perhaps feels belaboured about halfway through, and the book only really picks back up in the final few chapters.

I really enjoyed this book. Thought a bit dated now (written in 1993), it still offers a wealth of information about the "battle" between nature vs nurture. The author sees humans as a mix of the two, which is particularly interesting given today's hyper-PC world and the antics of the social sciences crowd who are so convinced there is nothing but nurture. Anyway, very interesting read.

Incredible. Rife with conjecture that will tickle your mind.The book is not "scientific" in that does not ram an idea down your throat. Each chapter has a problem that he is trying to solve. He describes the problem, various thoughts on the problem, and his opinion. Super well written and incredibly interesting. Definitely makes you go "Hmmmmm"

Disappointing. Author's style is to throw some random hypothesis together and retrofit subjective research to suit the suggested hypothesis. Hard to take anything he says seriously amid the egregious twisting in interpreting research results. The only saving grace was the references to animal research. They were far more interesting than the book itself.

A fascinating look at the science of sex. Why do we have sex as opposed to reproducing a-sexually? Who is manipulating who between the genders? How do our closest relatives behave sexually and what can we learn from them? How about not so close relatives? Etc.Human's are a monogamist species with a penchant for adultery... Sounds about right.

The bad: nothing in particular.The good: a comprehensive book on the effect of sex on human evolution. It touches a multitude of subjects ranging from intelligence to differentiation between individuals to the origin of other traits in individuals and populations. It's an excellent complementary read to Richard Dawkins's stuff.

Lots of unneeded facts. Not a particularly easy read, for a book, with such ideas.My advice : just read a review. It has loads of information and studies, depicting, that is already written and discussed in popular psychology.Of course, a couple of facts gave me some food for contemplation, regarding genes.A lot of it was skimmed by my eyes. The writer is not engaging, sorry.

This book no doubt will be boorish fodder for the massively burgeoning industry of dating/sex/intimacy coaches or even lovely PUA who teach attraction...because Science. There is so much more to the question "Why Sex?" than is contained within these pages. It's one verbose perspective written by a white aristocratic male.

Highly recommended for students in the field of behavioral ecology and the likes; Ridley reviews all the relevant research and manages to fit all weirdness of human nature together under one theory. Only downside is that some parts are outdated or old-fashioned, but if you endure that you will get rewarded with a really satisfying view on humans.

Interesting book that makes you think about sexuality, cheating, why men differ from women (besides the obvious way), and if we actually have a choice in our desires and sexual decisions or did our DNA set us up for disaster or success from the get go.

This book probably removed the last little crumbs of romanticism from my psyche. It should be called "Why do we look this way, like inexplicable things, act that way, and want to screw those people?" The answers are humbling. I'm a horny little monkey trying to get the most bananas.

A beautiful piece of scientific popularization by a dynamite author, Matt Ridley. All I can say is that any book about science which calmly talks about scientists gluing little paper hats onto finches gets a big thumbs up - for both humorous and educational value.
I didn't finish the whole book, but starts off (and by that I mean the first half or better) with an interesting biological approach as to why sex over asex. It was kinda dry so I couldn't finish it.

This is the earliest book I read about evolution, and was fascinated. It talks a lot about why we choose to mate with who we do. Also about the drive of our DNA to reproduce itself, and the difference between the male and female approach to reproduction.

If you are curious about why we act the way we act this book is priceless. If you are religious or even a hardcore evolutionist you may find it interesting, if you are open minded this book can fuck your brain.

while the first half of this book might be rough to get through, it sets the groundwork for a phenomenal second half. I've spoken about the points made in this book at countless gatherings and water cooler discussions, its just that fun.

Interesting book, but I was hoping that Ridley would go into more detail. The author was convincing in his defense of the basic idea of the Red Queen. However, I felt that he was really stretching the evidence at the end to make Red Queen be more all-encompasing than it really is.

Really thought I'd like this book better. It's a subject that normally interests me. It's hard for me to think of what, exactly, left me unmoved where this book was concerned, but my attention was never really caught by it, even after multiple attempts.

Really good; a milestone book in the understanding of genetics and personality. Also, it's something that's often referenced and alluded to, so even if you don't agree with the conclusions, it's important to read if you are at all involved in these arguments.

I skimmed this after about the first 100 pages, it was recommended to me by my sister Kim, who has a degree in evolutionary biology. It was very interesting to see the tie-ins between biology, economics, and sociology.

As far as genetics books go, this is my favourite...not that I've gotten too far in any others! Relatively readable and millions of interesting factoids...I love factoids. The world explained down to the gene.

Oh deary me - I tried reading this I really did and it was VERY interesting but then I had other things to do so gave up. I think it's something you could dip in to every once in a while when you feel the need to read something intellectual.

Some of the research is now obsolete, but Matt Ridley does an excellent job as always of making it accessible. None of the obsolete research that I've noticed thus far has seriously damaged his hypothesis, either, meaning this is still quite a worthy read.

Matt Ridley has a virtually unique capacity to synthesize and generalize about life. his writing intrigues, enlightens, and educates me. the red queen is either his best work or his second best. it naturally changes your view on life and the world. it is one of the top 5 books i have ever read.

I found it dragged on and on... Too many 1000s of animal stories without enough relating it to men/women.It seemed to also hem and haw a lot about the different schools of thought.I got to the end and didn't feel that I learned all that much...3 stars!

I've read this book over and over, when I thought it was lost in the fire I bought it again. I like books that help me understand human nature, why we do what we do. This book also explains the animal kingdom as well, and we aren't that far off from them.

Interesting hypothesis on the evolution of internal fertilization. Mr. Ridley and others take the stance that it is more for disease prevention than for any other reason (other than the obvious genetic benefits).

"We will never quite reach that goal, [complete understanding of human nature]... but as long as we can keep asking why, we have a noble purpose."A book about reproduction, genders, and sexuality. Easy to read, engaging examples, and intellectually titillating.

An interesting, if a little too detailed on the biological details, look at evolution and how we became what we are today. Exhaustive attention is paid to why humans are a sexual species and how they developed into what they are today. It was interesting but by no means a must read.

I might have enjoyed this book more if I'd read it closer to when it came out. Reading it almost a decade after it was released makes it seem rather ho hum, as much of what it espouses feels like common knowledge and less revolutionary then it might once have seemed.

The eponymous metaphor of Alice in Wonderland's Red Queen, that in evolution one must run as fast as one can just to stay in the same place, is excellent. There are sections, however, that just drag on and on. Mixed feelings, mixed rating.

Not as good as his other book Genome. However, it has lots of interesting ideas, but as he admits in the Epilogue, "Half the ideas in this book are probably wrong." It is a worthwhile read nevertheless.

I give props to any scientific book that concludes with, "mostly like 50% of this book is wrong..." Certainly an interesting read and a new way to look at selection, evolution, human nature, and a host of other science things that hurt my brain.

Lots of theories, some based on science, some not, about why humans and non-humans alike procreate. Ridley has an engaging style of writing that makes him likable even when you disagree with his conclusions.

Read this book as part of my course on Evolutionary theory....basically you just got to keep evolving to be better then your opposition to survive! Absolutely fantastic book, loved the bit at the end about Dolphins taking over the world - reminded me of Hitchhikers guide to the galaxy.

Although it starts dry and technical later on the extensively researched Red Queen is witty, clearly written and full of sound arguments and counter arguments. Highly recommended for everyone with the slightest interest in the evolution of sex and why sex exists. And who isn't?

This was an interesting attempt at analysis for how humans have evolved sexually and how it drove (driving) our societal structure. I'm a bit leery of the evolutionary psychology field, but the book made some interesting analogies and premises.

This book was outside my usual taste. Abounds with evolutionary theories rooted in parasitic behavior that sheds light on gene competition and the possible behavioral consequences in human sex. Definitely worth the read.

A good book. Gives you allot to think about in human nature, male female relationships and general evolution. I did find some of the details too technical and some of the idea's repetitive. Still, I would give the book a 9 out of ten but I can only give an 8 of 10 so it will be 8.

A really good book that tells the usefulness of sex biologically.A clear representation of sexual selection and why it normally doesn`t give completely outrageous forms.Ending on human sexuality with parental care and how sexual selection could have shapen the human brain though neoteny.

Informative, witty and fun to readThis is the book that first demonstrated to me the power of evolutionary psychology to help us understand ourselves. Published a year before Robert Wright's The Moral Animal, which covers much of the same territory, this is to my mind a more sophisticated and more direct exposition. Both books are characterized by a sly wit and an incisive expression, but Ridley meanders less among the relics of Freud and Darwin and is less concerned about whether we're moral or not and more concerned with what's sexy and why. He had a lot of fun with this book and it shows.The "red queen" is a metaphor for an arms race. In an arms race both sides run as fast and as hard as they can to stay in the same place relatively speaking. In evolution the arms race is between parasite and host or between predator and prey. Both are running as fast as they can just to keep up, because when one gets an advantage, the other finds a counter. The red queen comes from Lewis Carroll's Through the Looking Glass and What Alice Found There (1871) since that monarch ran as fast as she could but never got anywhere at all. The red queen is also a metaphor for the theory that there is no "progress" in evolution, that "...species do not get better at surviving... Their chances of extinction are random." (p. 64)Ridley covers a lot of territory here, ranging from sex to the handicap principle to gossip to why our brains are big (to figure out what the other person is up to!). The Red Queen answers the question, "Why is there sex?" Apparently we have sexuality rather than asexuality because of the arms race between microbes and our immune systems. Sex is a way of storing defenses against parasites in the gene pool of the species and then mixing them anew each generation to fool the microbes. Without the gene pool and the DNA mixing, the microbes would quickly evolve a way around the organism's defenses; but with sexuality the organism juggles its "locks" every generation and so is able to keep up with the fast-mutating microbes. When again the microbes evolve the keys to these locks, the gene pool is mixed again and the organism comes up with an old lock that the microbes again have to evolve a key to.Some of the fun is the incisive way Ridley presents the ideas, and the ideas he chooses to present. For example, note how effectively he demolishes Freud's naive incest taboo theory on pages 282-286. Also interesting is his presentation of the idea that it is not thinness in women per se that attracts men, but a low ratio of waistline to hip line that fetches them. There are chapters entitled "Polygamy and the Nature of Men," and "Monogamy and the Nature of Women." In Chapter 9, "The Uses of Beauty," Ridley goes into some detail on why men prefer thin and blond women. And on pages 217-218 he explains why women cuckold their mates: "This is because her husband is, almost by definition, usually not the best male there isâelse how would he have ended up married to her?" She wants the parental care of her husband and some other man's superiorâshe thinksâgenes.Ridley is rather modest and says that most of the ideas in the book are not his and at any rate many of them will undoubtedly be proven wrong. This is refreshing to read when I think about all the delusive ideas so proudly trumpeted by popular books on evolution and human behavior in the past. Desmond Morris's The Naked Ape (1967) and Elaine Morgan's The Aquatic Ape: A Theory of Human Evolution (1982) come to mind, both fine books, but now seen to be substantially mistaken.Written in an engaging and lucid style, The Red Queen really is the best of a number of books on evolutionary psychology to appear over the last decade and one that is a delight to read. --Dennis Littrell, author of âUnderstanding Evolution and Ourselvesâ

Matt Ridleyâs Red Queen is an excellent book for people who had never heard of sexual selection, mating systems, evolutionary psychology and human behavior from the biological sciences perspective. It explains quite clearly why it is necessary to think of a âhuman natureâ without the prejudice of the social scientists and âculturalistsâ, who tend to neglect human universals and genetic constraints. The book, in general, is easy to love and easy to dislike at the same time (in fact, Iâm very glad I finally finished it, yet Iâm sad I wonât have my daily night thinking). I loved it because it is a direct affront to postmodern thinkers, irrational feminists, early Freudians and social scientists in general. The author clearly despises shallow thinking and exhorts people to incorporate a wider view of human sexuality, letting moral judgements aside. The book was also a good review of behavioral biology topics, such as the evolution of sex (from group selectionists to modern individual selectionists, including Bellâs Tangle Bank hypothesis, Mullerâs Ratchet and Van Valenâs Red Queen), Fisherâs and Zahaviâs theories of runaway selection and good genes/handicap, respectively, and the differences between male and female minds (including humans) that arises from the fact that we are competing with each other ever since anisogamy emerged.However, Ridleyâs discourse feels sometimes a little messy, as if he wanted to explain many things at the same time (at least compared to Dawkins, for example). Also, he seems to be rather convinced about all Tooby and Cosmides evolutionary psychology arguments, which at present have been challenged by other authors such as Laland and Brown (advocates of an integral perspective, which includes behavioral ecology, cultural evolution and gen-culture coevolution as well). The book also ignores some fundamental issues when dealing with human minds, such as mental disorders and childhood maladaptive learning (Ridley mentions it very quickly at the end but in a rather disparaging manner). Finally, chapters 8 and 9 (Sexing the mind and The Uses of Beauty) present some debates which end up unresolved (a bit frustrating, I must say).The best ideas I got from this book were: 1)	Van Valenâs Red Queen theory can explain sex by giving a tremendous advantage for specimens who recombine their genes since there is a constant arms race against parasites, which otherwise would get quickly adapted to a specific set of genes.2)	Human monogamy is perpetuated by women, who benefit from not sharing paternal care and provisioning, but most importantly by men, because else many of them would not reproduce (polygamists would monopolize all females).3)	Young children DO behave differently. Boys tend to focus on objects when playing, whereas girls prefer to focus on people and language. Both sexes practice their best skills, and culture only reinforces such instincts.4)	Blond hair in adults may have arisen by sexual selection, rather than natural selection responding to climate pressures.5)	âNatureâ and ânurtureâ are so interdependent that almost any reasoning in favor of only one of this aspects is immediately wrong. Chomskyâs argument about language is the best example to prove it.The book gets 3.5 stars because, despite its great content and thorough explanations of human sex and evolution, Ridleyâs writing style made reading a burden. I would have given it 4 stars but I absolutely hated that every subtitle in each chapter was just unnecessary (and everytime I ended a reading session, next time I had to re-read last two sections). Apart from that, the book is a very nice compendium of simplified biological knowledge (and a bit of psychological theory, too). Recommended.

The Red Queen hypothesis: species do not get any better at surviving, their chances of extinction are random. "It takes all the running you can do to keep in the same place. If you want to get somewhere else, you must run at least twice as fast as that." Ridley then starts tracing the evolution of sex, beginning with the question: why sex? We take sex for granted, so much so that the question 'why sex?', looks absurd. But for evolutionary biologists, it is a great challenge. Suppose, in a sexual species, one individual decides (i.e. mutates to behave that way) to forego sex, he would put all his genes into each of his offsprings. A sexual individual puts only half of it. Therefore, the asexual is at a huge advantage. The second and third chapters are devoted to this riddle and the possible solutions. One of the most convincing answers is that sex is an adaptation to resist parasites. Hosts evolve genetic mechanisms to resist parasites and parasites evolve mechanisms to overcome them. But parasites have a shorter generation time, resulting in faster evolution. This advantage to parasites is countered by the hosts using sexual reproduction. Parasites of sexual species have to face a new gene combination in every generation. The result is an arms race in which nobody wins. Like the Red Queen in Lewis Carroll's âThrough the looking glassâ, who has to keep running to stay in the same place, the evolutionary race continues. Good science does not stop at the question 'why?'. It asks further 'why not?'. The fourth chapter discusses why two and only two sexes exist - male and female. Why not three or more or why not only one, for that matter? This is followed by a discussion of sexual selection. The obvious, but not as simple as we believe, answer to the question, why peacocks have beautiful tails - is sex. Ridley, so far, is talking nothing but frontline animal behaviour. With this background, from chapter six onwards, he ventures into the question of how human behaviour is shaped by the evolutionary drive called sex. What are the origins of love and lust, faithfulness and adultery, family bonds, social status, political ambitions, arts, and almost every aspect of human behaviour? Evolution of the human brain and development of languages also have a strong component of sexual selection without which we wouldn't have been what we are. These chapters are a complex series of surprises, provocations, consolations but they might feel a bit out-of-date given the book was written in 1993, over two and a half decades ago, when the various divisions of social and biological sciences may have been more at odds.The book ends with a very mature commentary on human nature. The discussion on the old debate on nature versus nurture is remarkably balanced. Ridley defies the popular belief that animals have more instinct and humans have more learning, asserting that humans have both, more instincts and more learning. "If we can free ourselves from the sterile- dogmatic dispute about nature and nurture, we can gradually uncover the rest (of the human behaviour map)." Overall, I found the book to be interesting, but some parts felt like a bit too much speculation, leaving me uncertain of what actually is the cause of various biological features. I wonder if this is why I donât read more non-fiction â I can trust the fiction to be fiction, but with non-fiction, Iâm constantly asking myself âhow does he know? And would I agree with his interpretation?â However, Ridley is a science journalist and not a researcher himself and has provided a lot of footnotes in the book to the actual research around many theories presented, in case anyone is interested to follow them up.

Poorly written and loaded with biology jargon, this one is really difficult to get through. The book delves into far too many theories on each and every subject it takes up, only to declare after a 3-page discussion that they've already been proven wrong. The metaphor 'The Red Queen' was overused and, to be honest, I didn't fully understand how the book came to its central conclusion - sex was invented to keep pathogens away. Only someone with a reasonably good knowledge of biology can appreciate it.Plus, it's highly European-centric. To the author's credit, he admits as much. However, he bases many of evolutionary psychology's conclusions on European trends - monogamy among emperors - which were far from the norm in other parts of the world. For instance, most Indian and Asian kings were hyper-polygamous, which puts paid to EP's claims of monogamy being inherent to men.European-centric or not, the book is riddled with flaws in its attempt to cement the primacy of nature over nurture, which is the central premise of EP. For example, to establish that men are inherently more promiscuous than women, it claims homosexual men sleep around more than their straight counterparts, a conclusion that is either strongly contested or simply wrong. Again, the books wrongly claims that there's something inherent about the appearance that men like in women (voluptuous and slim at the waist) and vice-versa (V-shaped body). This is demonstrably false, since men with big bellies were liked more during different periods of human history and anorexic women now have the upper hand over their voluptuous counterparts. Also, Greek male statues had small penises because these were indicators of culture, which is a U-turn from what we assume modern women like in men. The author struggles with a host of theories to explain these differences, but ends up avoiding the most obvious - what suits the eye is far more a function of idiosyncrasies and the prevalent culture than inherent nature.Having read this book and The Moral Animal back to back, along with a plethora of articles for and against EP, my conclusion is that no matter how fascinating and sometimes convincing, EP is ultimately much weaker a theory than what its evangelists would have us believe. Its two fundamental premises - procreation is the ultimate goal of every human action, and the human mind is biologically conditioned to follow instincts developed during the hunter-gatherer era - seem misplaced. I have discussed why the first is flawed here (https://www.goodreads.com/review/show...).For a very good discussion of why the agricultural revolution and subsequent changes are a better explanation of current human behaviour, please see the following reddit thread: https://www.reddit.com/r/FeMRADebates...

Four and a half stars for this one, I think. A clear and careful exploration, starting with why any creatures might reproduce sexually (since asexual reproduction is more certain of passing all your genetic material on to the next generation), then working through why there are almost always two genders, before tackling the thorny subject of gender differences in the animal kingdom. Finally, we get onto us humans, and the evolutionary story about behaviour differences between the genders. Even more than for many other animals, the evolutionary pressure in humans is to compete with other humans, rather than with environmental pressures: that's the Red Queen of the title. The faster we run, the faster others run, and the faster still we have to run to stay ahead. Today, even more than when the book was written in the early 1990s, this subject area is extremely fraught. Many would deny that gender differences are anything other than cultural, and the author goes to great lengths to explain the substantial evidence pointing to (a) their existence, and (b) their evolutionary origins, as opposed to cultural origins. I was a little worried that the 25 years or so since this book had been published would have produced new evidence that contradicted this thesis. Coincidentally, within a couple of hours of finishing the book, I came across well-reasearched current papers supporting the core points of the book: https://digest.bps.org.uk/2019/03/13/...We can see through these arguments that women are driven by evolution to want different things in their partners than men: on the whole, women are genetically programmed to seek to mate with men of status, so their genes get a leg up the power hierarchy, as higher-status men generally have higher-status children, and generally more of them. Meanwhile, men are programmed to seek younger women, as they may father more children by them. But as the book points out repeatedly, we have the significant capability to rise above our "programming": murder is entirely natural, but it doesn't mean we want it ruling our current society. So the question can still legitimately be asked as to whether we want to be like this: if so, how do we wish to set up our culture, and then, how might we judge those who fail to meet our new (culturally created) standards.
